statement.tex: %text Using integration, find the area of the triangle ABC, coordinates of whose vertices are $A(4,1), B(6,6)$ and $C(8,4)$. %
\\ %text Would $\triangle ABC$ be as shown in the figure below? %
\\ %text The \underline\text{equations of the sides} of the triangle will be as shown below. \textbf{Right or wrong?} %
\\ %text Given the equations of the sides, what will be the \underline\text{expression for the required area}? %

\\ %text What will be the values of $X,Y$ and $Z$ (below) and therefore of the required area $R$? % \begin{align} R &= \underbrace{\int_4^6\left( \frac{5x}{2}-9\right)dx}_X + \underbrace{\int_6^8(-x+12)dx}_Y \\ &-\underbrace{\int_4^8\left( \frac{3x}{4}-2\right)dx}_Z \end{align}

reason.tex:
%text On seeing the three given coordinates, we can see that (i) B is the highest point (largest y) (ii) A is the left-most point (smallest x) (iii) C is the right-most point (largest x) (iv) A is the lowest point (smallest y)
Hence, the coordinates, and therefore $\triangle ABC$, can only be as shown in the correct option. %

options.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Side} & \text{Equation} \\ \hline AB & y=\frac{5}{2}x-9 \\ \hline BC & y=-x+12 \\ \hline CA & y= \frac{3}{4}x -2 \\ \hline \end{tabular}

reason.tex: %text Apply the two-point formula to find the equations of the sides. % \begin{align} AB: \frac{y-1}{x-4} &= \frac{6-1}{6-4} = \frac{5}{2} \\ \implies 2y-2 &= 5x-20\implies y = \frac{5}{2}x -9 \\ BC:\frac{y-6}{x-6} &= \frac{4-6}{8-6} = -1 \\ \implies y-6 &= -x + 6 \implies y = -x + 12 \\ CA: \frac{y-1}{x-4} &= \frac{4-1}{8-4} = \frac{3}{4} \\ \implies 4y-4 &= 3x-12 \implies y=\frac{3}{4}x -2 \end{align}
